complaint_narrative:
A California consumer reports using a platform called AstraX, located at https://eaialliance.com, to trade crypto assets after learning about it through a WhatsApp group. The group members instructed the consumer how to engage in “margin” trading and provided trading signals they claimed would enable to consumer to make profitable trades. But, when the platform issued a purportedly fabricated margin call,  the consumer’s balance in their account disappeared.

The consumer has not been able to withdraw their funds from the platform, which is no longer operational. All told, the victim lost $5,000.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

Signal Selling Scam

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports being contacted by an individual online who asked to move the conversation to a messaging platform.  After forming a relationship, the “friend” brought up the topic of investing in crypto assets, and introduced the victim to a crypto asset trading platform located at b2c2-amm.com, saying they could engage in “joint-investing” where the “friend” would match whatever amount the victim invested. After a while the platform told the victim there was a potential “data-breach” and demanded $77,000 to withdraw their funds. The victim paid, but the platform demanded an additional $100,000 “investment” to fully withdraw their funds. The victim did not pay and has been unable to withdraw their funds. The website is no longer operational.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

Pig Butchering Scam

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports that after losing some crypto assets they received a letter from an “attorney” who claimed to work for a prominent law firm which could help recover the lost crypto assets.  The “attorney” referred the resident to a “technician” in the firm, who told the resident to deposit some crypto assets into an account so the law firm could ensure that the transaction was not money laundering. The resident deposited the funds, which then disappeared. The resident has not been able to recover any of the lost crypto assets and cannot contact the so-called law firm.

The DFPI urges consumers to exercise extreme caution before responding to any solicitation guaranteeing recovery of lost or stolen crypto or offering investment or financial services, especially if they ask you to pay upfront before delivering a product or service or ask you to provide personal information including account information.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports about their experience with an online crypto asset platform Lexor finance, located at webfinance.io. The resident saw a Facebook ad that claimed to be linked to a well-known CEO and said the platform used AI to help investors. Believing the ad, the resident sent funds to the bitcoin wallet address bc1qch8azpgn4vnykfmp2sqn8tlxw08z2xgk433jep. The victim reports they were not able to withdraw their funds and the website is no longer operational. All told the victim lost $5,000.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports on their experience with fraudulent platform, http://h5.miycoin.com/. The victim reports that they received a WhatsApp message to join a group where the group members would send trading signals. Following the group's instructions, the victim used h5.myicoin.com for cryptocurrency trading.  After engaging in multiple trades,  a person named “Professor Ivelyn” on the WhatsApp group demanded the victim to pay a 30% “tax” to the platform. The victim paid the “tax” but could not withdraw their funds without paying additional “taxes.” The website is no longer operational.
scam_type:
Investment Group Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports viewing a YouTube video which touted a crypto asset trading platform operating at owallet.com for trading. The victim opened an account on owallet.com and transferred some crypto assets to sell there. But when the victim tried to withdraw their funds, the platforms’s customer service rep said their account was frozen and demanded they deposit $25,000 in their owallet account to complete the withdrawal. The victim has been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer operational.

The blogger invited the victim to open an account on the crypto asset trading platform, Global Capitals at https://app.globalcapitalsgc.com, and convinced the victim to transfer funds into their account to trade for profits. The victim did so, and believed they were making profits trading along with the blogger. But when the victim tried to withdraw their funds the platform denied their request. Then the blogger messaged the victim and told them to send more to the platform which would help with the withdrawal. The victim did so, but was still unable to withdraw their funds. The victim has been unable to recover their funds, and the website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports seeing an ad on Instagram that when clicked on, led them to the Telegram group, “SB Signal Sniper”. The group was led by a “Professor” and “Assistant” who said they would provide trade signals to the group which could be profitable, if they opened an account and traded on the crypto asset trading platform operating at  http://coingrocer.net/. The victim opened an account on the platform, deposited funds, and followed the trading signals, believing they were making profits. But when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay “mining fees”. The victim paid, but the platform requested an additional $3,000 for “computing power”. The victim has been unable to recover any funds and the website is no longer operational. All told, the resident lost at least $6,000 on the platform.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

Aileen told the resident how their aunt was a successful investor that owned properties in France and Croatia. At some point Aileen steered the conversation to investing in crypto assets, and suggested the victim start a “blockchain savings plan” on the crypto asset trading platform located at web3app.rest, claiming she had made money. After investing small amounts of money into the “short term savings plan”, the victim was able to withdraw some of their funds. Encouraged, the victim deposited more money onto the platform. At some point, the victim was asked to deposit $500,000 for “security fees.” The victim refused and now cannot withdraw their funds. The website is no longer operational. All told the victim lost more than $2.5 million on the platform.

complaint_narrative:
Two California residents report about their experience with two fraudulent platforms, official-xai.com and https://xai-network.com/home/. The first victim reports that they watched a video that linked to the “xAI token” presale on official-xai.com. The victim reports that they saw a fake video of “Elon Musk” talking about the coin which led them to believe that the offering was legitimate. The victim then initiated a swap for their DOGE coin and put in more than the minimum due to the promise of attractive “bonuses”. After engaging in multiple “successful” transactions with official-xai.com, the victim reports that official-xai.com told the victim they could receive a larger bonus if they made another presale purchase. The victim then transferred USDT and did not receive any coins in return. The website is now defunct. The victim reports sending cryptocurrency to the following wallet addresses:

c4473f3d60ebc2c48ee00ac4a7dd44a19e5f131c596cac047d1bae081514099c
DTLcykDRKbgQ8AKsnnnKP9WwZuVD1sFAan
DKFXeqPcv4s8nFB4pZxjfu2hwjV8LkwXNz
DTLcykDRKbgQ8AKsnnnKP9WwZuVD1sFAan

The second victim reports that they clicked on the link found in a YouTube video and decided to invest on fraudulent platform, https://xai-network.com/home/. The victim sent 2,300 XRP tokens to https://xai-network.com/home/ to swap for the “xAI token” as part of the presale. After sending the XRP tokens and communicating with “customer service”, the victim reports not receiving the “xAI tokens” in return. The platform is no longer available.

The above sites are not affiliated with the company, xAI.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
Multiple people report on their experiences with a crypto asset trading platform operating at the website usdcbtc.cc:

A California victim was introduced to the site through a WhatsApp group called “Star Navigation Capital”.  The group was led by a trading guru “Jason” and his assistant “Caroline”.  At first, Jason and Caroline gave stock tips, but after a few weeks, Jason encouraged group members to trade ICOs (initial coin offerings) on usdcbtc.cc.  Based on Jason’s advice, the victim took out a large loan and transferred funds to the site.  The victim was able to withdraw small portions of their account balance.  But when the victim tried to withdraw a more substantial sum, the platform demanded they pay a large withdrawal fee first.  The victim has been unable to recover their money.  All told they lost more than $330,000 on the website.

A second California victim reports they also opened an account and transferred funds to usdcbtc.cc for crypto trading.  Over time, the victim believed they made more than $1.4 million from crypto trading.  The victim reports they were also initially able to withdraw smaller sums of money from the site.  But when the victim tried to withdraw a larger sum, the site demanded they pay a 10% withdrawal fee.  The victim has since been unable to withdraw their money. All told, they lost approximately $60,000 on the website.

An out-of-state victim reported that they were referred to usdcbtc.cc by a friend who claimed to be making “easy money trading on crypto”.  The friend referred the victim to a WhatsApp group called “Celestial Investment Crew”, also led by Jason and Caroline.  Jason encouraged group members to drain any stock accounts so they can deposit money on the site.  Following Jason and Caroline’s instructions, the victim opened an account and transferred funds to buy ICOs. They have been unable to withdraw any of their funds. All told they lost at least $10,000 on the website.

A second out-of-state victim also reported usdcbtc.cc.  The victim invested $5,000 and believed they made $11,000 in trading gains.  They have been unable to withdraw any of it.  The website is no longer operational.

The victims identified the following Ethereum wallets as part of the scam:

0x0d113Bd8F4D9Cf77d02Dcb036C4E54dDF3A3835E
0x925b13608a9D7B65Bf5d55DD528488A33A43cbFF

0x8bdfeaff0a7d9d7fa67309da1c793ed979f645eb

The victims also identified the following Bitcoin wallets as part of the scam:

3AMCzuPvuFsQFb3XAcAK2kfUVcWfkGvE1g
1FCpLh7v3iBm5a5Pt2QhRDy4se6U8PgFT8
3GpokEfKuY3ZuKxVaLzdZ8JTzQ3jtoG8K2

Finally, the victims identified one TRON wallet as part of the scam:

TCDmtc4qVdPzmeqmKNZoCW5M2cwxHmD4eb

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
Two California residents reported about their experiences investing on the crypto asset trading platform Up-Business. The first victim was approached by “Raddy” on Facebook who suggested they continue their conversations on WhatsApp. Over time, Raddy began introducing the resident to crypto asset trading and eventually convinced the resident to invest with Raddy on the trading platform, located at the website up-business.top. Raddy convinced the victim they used an AI trading program that would generate stable returns. Following Raddy’s instructions the victim invested funds on the platform and believed they were earning substantial profits on the platform. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds from the platform, they were not able to. All told the victim lost more than $55,000 on the platform. The resident reported sending crypto to 0xB10ABECA64cf19d37c45045a5851BB528fB21E47. 

The second victim was approached by “Reddy” on WhatsApp who convinced them to  create an account and transfer funds to a crypto asset trading platform located at up-business.business. Reddy convinced the victim they could earn profits with an AI-based crypto asset trading program, but they needed to make a minimum of five trades. The victim made the five trades and believed they had made a profit on the platform. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform’s customer support demanded they deposit additional funds and engage in five more trades first. Reddy encouraged the victim to do this, and soon the victim believed their account had grown to more than $100,000. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds again, the platform demanded they pay 10% of the withdrawal before it would release the funds. The victim has been unable to recover any funds and the platform is no longer operational.
scam_type:
Pig Butchering Scam

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports that they were contacted on Instagram by a stranger, who eventually asked that they move the conversations to WhatsApp. At some point, the stranger introduced them to Crypto futures trading on fraudulent platform, ApolloX, operating at the website apolloxxap.com. The victim invested, and believed they were making profitable trades, but when they to withdraw their funds, the ApolloX helpdesk told the resident they suspected “malicious trading” in the account and demanded a $10,400 “security fee”. The resident paid the “tax” but the platform told them that since their account had past issues, they would have to wait to make a withdrawal, unless they purchased a “VIP membership” for $50,000. The victim contacted the stranger who suggested that if the victim could pay $10,000 to ApolloX the stranger would pay the remaining $40,000 for the “VIP membership.” But even after obtaining the VIP membership, ApolloX demanded an additional $20,000 in “withdrawal fees”. The resident has not been able to withdraw their funds and the website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative: A Californian reports on their experience trying to buy a crypto token called “Propichain” ($PCHAIN), on the website propichain.finance.  The victim sent money to Propichain but never received any tokens.  When the victim complained to Propichain’s customer support team, their login credentials were blocked.  The victim has not been able to recover any of their money and the website is no longer operational. All told the victim lost $20,000.

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports meeting an individual on an international dating app, Bumpy. After talking for a few months, the individual encouraged the resident to start investing on crypto asset trading platform, btc01.org. The website is no longer operational. The victim reports losing more than $46,000.

complaint_narrative:
A California consumer discovered Crypto-Networks.net through a promotional YouTube video and decided to use the platform to invest in cryptocurrency. After making a few small deposits that appeared to work, the consumer deposited more crypto assets. Following that deposit, the platform abruptly froze the consumer’s account.

When the consumer contacted support, the platform demanded they upgrade to “Titan Status” before they could withdraw funds. The upgrade cost $10,000, which the consumer paid by transferring more crypto assets. Despite transferring the funds, the consumer’s account remained frozen, and the platform stopped responding. The site is no longer in operation and the consumer has not retrieved any of their funds.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

primary_subject:
Lencoin Tech 
LNO LNN LEN GO 
h5.lencoin.vip
complaint_narrative: Five California residents report on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform Lencoin, which operated on the website www.h5.lencoin.vip. The residents all learned about Lencoin from visiting the website, wealthtutor.com, where a person named “Clark” discussed opportunities to make big profits by investing in crypto coins and using trade signals through Telegram or Whatsapp groups. Clark directed the residents to open accounts on Lencoin to make the trades, and the residents subsequently  transferred their cryptocurrency to Lencoin. The residents believed their accounts were rapidly growing but were met with various excuses when they tried to withdraw funds such as the transaction being flagged for a "money laundering check". Some residents were directed to transfer additional fund as a prerequisite to withdrawal. The residents did not recover their invested funds. Both www.h5.lencoin.vip and wealthtutor.com are no longer operational.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

Signal Selling Scam

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports about the experience with the so-called investment education platform, “Digital Finance Academy” which offered access to a “Trader Incubation Program” called the “Stable Trading System 6.0 investment system”. To participate in the program, the resident paid $50,000 in crypto assets, believing they could net 300% through the issuance of a crypto asset Academy Token (“STS”). Digital Finance Academy claimed that once they had sold enough tokens to reach their target the resident would get their returns, though would have to pay 30% to the academy for various subscription/service-related fees. But after participating in the program, the platform demanded $54,000 for “commissions” before allowing any withdrawals. The resident has not been able to recover their funds and the investment program is no longer operational. 

The DFPI cautions consumers to be wary of entities purporting to be investment education platforms offering access to proprietary investment programs or technologies to solicit investment in crypto. These entities may promise unusually high returns in vague investment opportunities that appear to be sophisticated or complex (e.g. algorithmic trading systems, AI-driven strategies, etc.) and may even have consumers sign into an investment contract to appear legitimate.
scam_type:
Signal Selling Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident was contacted via social media and WhatsApp by “Samiya” who claimed to be associated with a well-known investment firm based in San Diego. Samiya promised high returns from investing in crypto and told the victim to download a crypto wallet app. Samiya then provided instructions on how to open an account on pzmqgow.top and send funds to the platform from the wallet app encouraged the victim to make multiple deposits. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform’s customer service demanded fees to release their funds. The resident has not been able to recover any funds and the website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports meeting an individual on an online dating app who introduced them to short-term crypto asset trading. At the direction of the individual, the victim deposited money onto the platform to begin trading. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay $275,000. The victim did not pay, and the individual they met on the dating app stopped responding. The victim has been unable to recover any funds from the platform and the website is no longer operational. complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports about their experience with the crypto asset trading platform, VOEX or Voexe. The resident reports that the platform promised a reward of 118,888 USDT if investor deposits exceeded one million by a certain date. When the victim was unable to meet the deadline, Voexe deducted 100,000 USDT from the victim’s account, and demanded even more funds if the victim wanted to withdraw the balance of their account. 

Based on a screenshot provided by the victim, the platform operated under web domains voex.com and voexit.com, and appears to mimic the look and interface of another crypto trading platform. However, the logo used by the platform is stolen from the robotics solutions company, Vectis Automation. This is not to be confused with Vectis Automation at https://vectisautomation.com/.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports seeing an Instagram profile whose "bio" displayed a promo code for the BitexOne.com, purportedly offering 0.12 BTC to sign up with the code ABTC12, with the Instagram account featuring various photos of Elon Musk.  The resident visited the site, provided their personal information, but did not receive the promised crypto assets. The website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports that they were contacted on Facebook by someone asking if they would like to invest in cryptocurrency. After viewing the individual’s Facebook profile, filled with testimonials from other individuals purchasing new cars and houses crediting the platform, the resident reached out saying they were interested. The individual instructed the victim how to open an account to begin trading on the crypto asset trading platform operating at xplivetrade.com, promising a return of $5,500 in three days. After three days, the victim’s account on the platform showed a profit of $60,000. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded 15% of the earnings. The victim paid, but the platform demanded another $7,000 fee to convert the crypto assets to cash. The victim reached out to the person they met on Facebook, who said if the victim gave them $1,500 they would get the money back in their bank account in 20 minutes. The victim refused, and has been unable to withdraw their funds from xplivetrade.com. The website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative:
Two California residents report about their experience with the crypto asset trading platform, CBMWW, operating at wwww.cbmww.com. 
The first California resident indicated they were messaged on Facebook by someone claiming to be a crypto investor. The Facebook investor asked to move the conversations over to WhatsApp, and then presented an investment opportunity involving bitcoin trades, promising high returns. All told the victim invested more than$400,000 and stated that they can no longer access their cryptocurrency. The victim reports the domain name changed several times, and reports encountering the following domains: 
bittisport.com, nvbit.cc, frbit.cc, cbmww.com

The second California resident reports being approached by “Yinan” on Facebook. Yinan told the resident she had a successful business and was planning to retire early. When the resident inquired about this, Yinan claimed to have an uncle who managed a team of analysts that could determine which crypto asset to invest. Yinan showed business statements to the resident to prove she had made solid returns. Yinan then directed the resident to open an account on the crypto asset trading platform, CBMWW, operating at www.cbmww.com. The victim initially invested and was able to withdraw their first profit of $1,000. After that Yinan enticed the resident to deposit more funds, claiming she would regularly provide information about upcoming markets to trade in along. At one point, the resident believed that their account had grown to more than $1 million. But when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform’s customer support demanded the resident pay the “Cryptocurrency Regulatory Authority” a $260,000 tax . Yinan offered to help pay half of the tax, but the victim realized she was only trying to gain access to their crypto asset wallet. All told, the resident lost over $179,000. The websites are no longer operational.

The resident reported sending cryptocurrency to the following wallet addresses:
0xb1ee662001a0247270b282e03cfc0c86642babec
0xa5fe0f74911715f5d6290d39da823c8e15986554
scam_type:
Pig Butchering Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports encountering a crypto coin offering offered at the web domain, Tesladigital.us. The website touted plans to go public, but continually push back the coin’s anticipated launch date. At one point, the website claimed there were only two days left to purchase “Teslacoin” (TES) as an early investor before it would close for 6 months. The victim decided to invest at $0.95 a share. Later the webiste claimed ES had increased to $17.57 which led the victim to believe their investment was worth $175,000. However, the when the victim tried to withdraw  funds, the website claimed the shares were restricted until the offering goes public. The resident been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer operational. 

This is not to be confused with Tesla or any of its ongoing products and services at https://www.tesla.com/. The DFPI warns consumers to remain vigilant against scams fraudulently using the Tesla name, brand, or likeness to promote fake investment opportunities or giveaways. These schemes often appear on social media or spoofed websites, falsely claiming affiliation with Tesla or its executives, and may promise guaranteed returns, free cryptocurrency, or exclusive investment offers. The DFPI encourages consumers to verify the legitimacy of an investment opportunity before sending funds and reporting suspicious activity to the appropriate financial authorities.
scam_type:
Rug Pull Scam

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform, Octal Capital, at octal-capital.com. The resident started with a small investment of less than $200 and believed the account  grew to more than $83,000 on the platform. But when the victim tried withdraw their funds, a representative from the platform said they needed to purchase additional “programs” before they could make a withdrawal and offered the $43,000 “Mega Plan.” The victim sent funds to purchase the Mega Plan, but when they tried to withdraw their funds from the platform, it demanded an additional $5,000 payment for “gas fees.” The platform instructed the victim to send crypto assets the following wallet address: 0xcfE181465c0c750F3d914bb9a9805e96a6d6AbDa.  
The victim paid, but then learned the platform transferred their funds to an address on a different blockchain network. The victim contacted the platform and spoke with "Sagar," who claimed to be a representative of the platform. However, Sagar demanded a “tax percentage fee” as a condition of unlocking the funds. The victim has been unable to recover their funds and the website is no longer in operation.

At some point, the individual convinced the victim to invest in a crypto asset trading platform, at Hikkod.com. Following the individual’s instruction, the victim opened an account and transferred money to the platform. The individual claimed to have hired an analyst to provide tips in trading crypto options. The victim continued to trade until they believed their account had grown to more than $570,000. complaint_narrative:
A California consumer was introduced to short-term crypto asset trading by a person calling themselves Caroline. Following Caroline’s instructions, the victim transferred crypto assets from their wallet to an online crypto trading platform called Dex Defi, located at  www.dex-defi.com. After some time, the consumer thought they were making trading profits. But when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform’s customer service informed the consumer that the account had “insufficient turnover” and required additional trading before any withdrawal could be processed.

The consumer then executed several trades to satisfy this requirement. But when they tried to make another withdrawal, the platform’s customer service demanded $9,000 in “profit taxes” before allowing any funds to be released. 

The platform’s website is no longer in operation, and the consumer has not recovered any funds deposited on the platform.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California consumer reports on their experience with the crypto trading platform called GCRA, or gcra2024.com. Believing that they had earned profits trading in their account, the consumer requested a withdrawal. But GCRA customer service demanded a 10% margin deposit of $800 before it would release funds. The consumer deposited $800, but the withdrawal was never processed. The site is no longer in operation, and the consumer has not retrieved any of their funds.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
A California consumer was contacted via WhatsApp by “Chris,” who claimed he worked as an engineer and traded crypto assets on the side. Chris instructed the consumer to install a Wallet app and add the platform bkchaintops.com.

Over the course of two months, the consumer wired assets to an international bank in Vietnam to invest on the platform. Initial small deposits appeared to yield returns, encouraging the consumer to make further deposits. Concurrently, Chris pressured the consumer into making additional deposits, promising high rates of profit. Chris also convinced the consumer to enroll in a subscription after the platform threatened to freeze their assets unless they deposited more money. 

The victim followed Chris’s instructions, but when they tried to withdraw funds, the platform displayed a “processing” status, and customer service claimed the account was flagged for suspected money laundering and demanded the victim deposit 30% of the total balance and additional funds to unfreeze the account. The consumer refused and has not recovered any of their deposits. The site is no longer in operation. All told, the victim lost more than $300,000.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports on their experience investing in an online commodity company called Cometa Global Limited operating at http://info@cometaglobal.email. After investing on the company’s online platform, the resident tried to make a withdrawal. The platform demanded they pay a “security risk management fee”. Despite paying the fee on multiple occasions, the resident has yet been able to withdraw any funds. At this point, the resident realized this to be a scam and reported the incident. The victim has been unable to retrieve their funds from the platform. The website is no longer operational. All told they lost more than $130,000 including the fees.
scam_type: Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports they were contacted by Diana via WhatsApp, who offered them a job as a freelance crypto asset miner for the RIOT Blockchain platform, with no restrictions or set schedule and the ability to work remotely. The victim accepted the offer, completed all their training and was ready to begin working as a miner. At that point, the platform demanded the victim deposit their own funds first. The victim did so and worked daily, getting rewards for completing each task. However, the platform kept asking the victim to deposit increasing amounts of their own money to continue working. Further, the platform wouldn’t allow withdrawals unless the victim increased their “credibility rating” by depositing more funds. Eventually, the victim had to borrow money to continue to be able to work on the RIOT mining platform. Despite depositing nearly $81,000, the platform never allowed the victim to withdraw their funds. 

This is not to be confused with the investment company, Riot Platforms at https://www.riotplatforms.com/

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports that they were a victim of an investment scam involving the entity Spark Capital, which sought “testers” for a software program called SPARK PPAP Wisdom System that purported to deliver AI-powered cryptocurrency trading signals.

The California resident reports seeing ads for an AI cryptocurrency software company on Facebook. The company, Spark Capital, was looking for “testers” of its software program, SPARK PPAP Wisdom System that purportedly gave AI-powered cryptocurrency trading signals. The ad featured prominent media personalities who claimed that “they were going to make 10 people millionaires within the next 2 weeks.” SPARK Capital claimed it would give each tester crypto assets to fund an account on the platform which they would then use to trade crypto assets. But then they told the resident they needed to pay  $5,000 to get the trading signals. Later, SPARK Capital increased the amount to $50,000. The victim transferred large sums of money to the platform based on promises of high returns from between 500% to 2000%. But now the victim is unable to withdraw any of their funds. primary_subject:
TBAAPro.com
(Entity Impersonating Tech Brokerage Asset Alliance LTD)
complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports on their experience with the crypto asset trading app, TBAAPro.com, which they learned about from a community on WhatsApp that gave advice about investing in crypto. The WhatsApp group, AWC-K154 Wealth Creators, was led by administrators who claimed to be part of a brokerage company called Tech Brokerage Asset Alliance (TBAA) and claimed to be licensed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Following the group’s instructions, the resident downloaded the TBAA app and began trading on the platform. At one point, they believed their account held more than $100,000. They were even able to withdraw some funds at first. But when they tried to withdraw $50,000, the platform said it was conducting an “IRS verification” process and demanded that the resident pay a capital gains tax on their investment gains. The victim has been unable to withdraw their funds, and the app is no longer operational.

This is not to be confused with the SEC registered issuer, Tech Brokerage Asset Alliance LTD (CIK:0002030953). Please note that scammers may use information from public filing databases to appear legitimate. When receiving unexpected investment solicitations through messaging apps from people claiming to represent a licensed company, the Department recommends looking up the company’s contact information online and reaching out to confirm that the solicitation is legitimate.
scam_type:
Investment Group Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:

In September 2024, Dolan launched a “Joint Trade Wealth Multiplication Plan,” and claimed more participants were joining rapidly, but warned against withdrawing funds. Shortly thereafter, the consumer received an email from support@biticrypto.com demanding a $72,000 fine be sent to the crypto wallet address: 0xAA3B939F645aA35CA830940B616919519F10C397

Other group members also received demands from Biticrypto to pay a fine. Panic spread in the group, but Denise instructed members pay the fines to the platform. BKEX refused to deduct the tax from the account balance and declined to cite any specific tax regulations justifying the demand. The consumer decided to invest $1 million on the platform. After the coin launch, VIPIDO.net represented that the investment had appreciated and could be converted to USDT. However, when the victim tried to sell the coin, the platform demanded an “institutional fee” of $188,000, payable only via wire transfer.

After paying the fee and selling the token, the consumer attempted to withdraw their profits but the platform demanded a 0.4% "gas fee" of $258,000. After paying, the platform then demanded a $140,800 "expedite fee," and finally demanded an additional $50,000 “tip” to release the funds. The consumer declined to pay these fees. The victim has been unable to withdraw any of their funds and the VIPIDO.net website is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reports about their experience with a crypto-forex trading site called GSG Forex, at www.forexgsg.com.  The victim was introduced to the site by a Skype group called “MT4 Forex Trading Million Dollar Club”, within which an individual claiming to be a  trading guru named James and his assistant Nina gave forex trading signals to traders.  Nina helped the victim create an account on the GSG Forex exchange, which the victim funded with $13,000 in crypto assets.  After a few weeks of trading, the victim believed they had made $30,000.  

However, when the victim tried to withdraw money from their account, Nina told the victim to pay a 20% commission for the trading signals.  After the victim paid, a customer service representative for GSG told the victim they had to pay several taxes to a Hong Kong government agency before they could make a withdrawal, including a 20% personal income tax, a 10% offshore income tax, and a 15% stamp duty.  In total, the victim paid over $20,000 for these taxes and commissions, but was never allowed to withdraw any money.  Instead, their GSG Forex account was deleted and the GSG rep stopped communicating with the victim.  The victim contacted Nina, who provided contact info for a new customer service rep.  This time, the new GSG rep demanded an additional $4,000 “withdrawal deposit”, and threatened that if the victim did not pay within an hour, the entire account balance would be donated to charity.  The victim paid, and then was told that the initial GSG rep they had dealt with had diverted $20,000 of the victim’s money to their own personal wallet.  The new GSG rep offered to work with Hong Kong securities officials to recover the lost payments, but said that the securities regulators required the victim to pay another $6,500 deposit because the victim resided outside of Hong Kong.  Then, Nina told the victim to reimburse her for $2,000 claiming she had paid a fee on the their behalf.  When the victim refused, Nina said if they paid half ($1,000), she could still get the victim’s money back.  After that, all of the characters associated with GSG Forex cut contact with the victim.  The victim has not been able to recover any of their money, and the site is no longer operational.
scam_type:
Investment Group Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative: A California resident reports about their experience with multiple crypto asset trading platforms, including bybtcoim-vip.top, zaifusw.com, and nextran.top. First, the victim met Lisa online who claimed to live in New York City. Lisa introduced the victim to the trading platform bybtcoim. Following Lisa’s instructions, the victim opened an account and transferred funds to trade. At one point, the victim believed their account had grown to more than $3 million. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded $350k to release funds.  All told, the victim lost $527,000 on the platform. The website is no longer operational. Next, the victim met Luisa online who claimed to be from San Francisco. Luisa gave the victim a loan of $100,000 to deposit on the Zaif platform to trade crypto assets. But later the platform demanded $30,000 from the victim. The website is no longer operational. Then the victim met Susan, who also claimed to be from San Francisco and told the victim that his previous crypto asset investments were fakes. She told him about another crypto asset trading platform, nextran.top, where the victim could really make money. Susan said she had invested her own money on the platform, and convinced the victim to invest as well. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay $100,000 first. Susan said she was a victim, too. All told the victim lost $215,000 to that platform. The website is no longer operational.  This is not to be confused with the Japan based exchange, Zaif, at https://zaif.jp/.

complaint_narrative:
Two California consumers report on their experience with the crypto asset trading platform Bitagold. 

The first consumer was contacted by an individual on a social media messaging platform who claimed to offer guidance on making profits through cryptocurrency options trading, specifically involving Ethereum (ETH). The individual directed the consumer to the "Bitagold" platform accessible via the websites ghfyrh.ac and zymomer.cc. 

The social media friend guided the victim through multiple trades on the platform, and said they were earning 60–70% on each transaction. Encouraged by these gains, the consumer invested increasing amounts of money on the platform.

But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded that they victim pay short-term capital gains tax in crypto assets first. When the consumer was unable to pay the entire tax immediately, the platform froze their account and demanded more money to reactivate it. The victim has been unable to recover their funds from the platform.

A second California consumer reports they joined a stock trading group chat that recommended investing money on Bitagold. The victim deposited crypto assets on the platform has been unable to withdraw any money from Bitagold. The platform is no longer operational.

The victim deposited $75,000, but in just a few minutes, the platform informed them that they lost everything.  The victim has not been able to recover any of their money.

The second resident reports that they were approached on LinkedIn by Vivian. complaint_narrative: A California resident reports being approached by “Kevin” on a popular dating app, claiming to be an investor in real estate, stocks, and cryptocurrency, as well as an IT manager and Director of Operations at a major intentional hotel chain.  After offering to teach the resident how to trade crypto, Kevin led the resident to send funds to the fraudulent trading platform, Zipmexpro, at https://zipmexpro.com. Through trade signals provided by Kevin, the resident was led to believe they were engaging in bitcoin options trading. After making an initial profit, Kevin showed the resident how to transfer funds from Zipmexpro back to their bank account to encourage the resident to continue trading on the platform. After a month of trading, Kevin introduced another investment opportunity that he wanted them to be a part of. Kevin told the resident that he had an aunt who used to work at NASDAQ and worked with a group of experts in bitcoin options trading. Kevin’s aunt purportedly gave him an $8 million quota in preparation for an upcoming investment opportunity that would take place in a month. The resident liquidated their brokerage account to participate in the investment. A few weeks later, Kevin told the resident he was short $500,000 in preparation for the $8 million trading signal and convinced the resident to liquidate their retirement accounts to make up the difference. After the execution of the $8 million trade signal, Kevin claimed the trade resulted in a $1.6 million loss but introduced another $12 million investment opportunity and convinced the resident to take out personal loans in order to participate. However, days after the execution of the purported investment the platform was shut down. All told, the investor reported losing over $3.8 million to Zipmexpro. The website is no longer operational.  The trading platform appears to be a spoof of the Singapore and Thailand based exchange, Zipmex. This is not to be confused with Zipmex at https://zipmex.com/.

complaint_narrative:

Nathan and Amy convinced followers to set up trading accounts on DYDX Wallet where they could trade based on Nathan’s advice.  

Following Nathan and Amy’s instructions, the victim opened an account on DYDX Wallet and transferred money into it.  Nathan charged a fee to provide trading signals for the victim to follow, and the victim believed they had turned a quick profit.  But when the victim tried to withdraw money from their account, the site demanded they pay $3,000 more in commission to Nathan.  The victim paid but was not able to withdraw their balance. complaint_narrative:
Two Californians report about the crypto asset trading app, MIC Markets, at micmarkfx.com.  The first victim was introduced to MIC Markets by someone they met online.  The online acquaintance persuaded the victim to deposit $45,000 into a trading account on MIC Markets.  Over time, the victim believed they had doubled their money trading crypto assets.  At first, the victim was able to withdraw small amounts of money from their trading account.  But, when the victim tried to withdraw their total balance, their withdrawal was blocked.  The site demanded that the victim pay ”taxes” before they could withdraw.  They have since been unable to withdraw anything.

The second victim was introduced to MIC Markets by someone they met on a popular dating app.  After moving the conversation to WhatsApp, the romantic interest asked the victim to join him in investing money to create a strong financial future together.  The romantic interest asked the victim to download a Bitcoin wallet app and the MIC Markets trading app.  The imposter then appeared to add $1,000 to the victim’s account and executed a few trades, quickly making a 25% profit.  Based on this demonstration, the victim transferred 
thousands of dollars to their MIC Markets account, believing they would be able to turn a similar profit.  But then the romantic interest bullied the victim into funding their account with even more money, either from their 401(k) or from personal loans.  The victim subsequently took out a $20,000 loan and transferred it to their MIC Markets account.  

Once the victim’s profit reached $50,000, they tried to withdraw it.  But MIC Markets refused to process the withdrawal and demanded a 20% fee.  The romantic interest promised to pay part of the fee if the victim paid the rest using money from their 401(k).  At some point, the victim discovered that the romantic interest had used someone else’s photos and information to create a fake dating profile.  Soon after, MIC Markets blocked the victim from accessing their account at all.  The site is no longer operational.  In total, the victim lost about $20,000 to MIC Markets.
scam_type:
Pig Butchering Scam

Fraudulent Trading Platform

John introduced the victim to a global digital currency exchange platform called coinefxiih.com, claiming that this platform was safe, secure and trustworthy. Following John’s instructions, the victim believed they were making profits from their crypto investments and was even able to withdraw some money. But when the victim tried to withdraw more funds, Coinefx customer service said they had frozen the victim’s account because of “suspiciously high profits”, and demanded the victim pay 10% of the account value. The victim had to borrow money from family to pay this amount. When they tried to make another withdraw, the website demanded they pay another 8% of the account value to have a “blockchain technologist” involved. All told they transferred more than $40,000 to the website, which is no longer operational.

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reports meeting someone on LinkedIn who invited them to chat on WhatsApp, where they suggested earning money by crypto trading.  The person introduced the victim to the crypto trading site called trusflow.com and taught them how to exchange cash for crypto assets and then transfer funds to the site for trading.  The victim tested the site with $1,000 and believed they had made a profit.  

Over a couple months, the victim deposited more money into their account on trusflow.com and believed they had made nearly $500,000 in profit.  But when the victim tried to withdraw money from their account, trusflow.com demanded they pay a $100,000 “large volume trading commission” first.  The victim paid this fee but was then told that they needed to pay an additional $100,000 “green channel fee” to expedite the withdrawal, which would later be refunded to the victim.  The victim paid this fee, too, but Trusflow.com then requested an additional $75,000 “security deposit” (which they promised would also be refunded).

In total, the victim lost over $300,000 and has not been able to recover any of their funds from trusflow.com.  The person they met on LinkedIn cut off all communication with the victim and the website is no longer operational.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform
Pig Butchering Scam

complaint_narrative:
Several Californians report a WhatsApp investment group called DAF Finance Institute.  The group claimed to offer a new crypto trading product they had developed called “AI Profit Algorithms 4.0”, available through a crypto asset trading platform referred to as OPACOIN, OPNCOIN, or OPN-GO.  The group claimed they had received funding for the product from legitimate sources such as FINRA, and that the product was in the final stages of testing.  DAF Finance Institute promised members that the product would allow them to trade cryptocurrencies before the initial coin offering (ICO’s) and would help them make large profits after the ICO occurred.  DAF said that the volatility of the crypto market brought potential for immense profit.

At first, the group gave members a $500 trial investment to use on the OPACOIN platform.  Several Californians report watching their trial investments grow, and that they were even able to successfully withdraw the initial $500.  After the trial investment period, DAF group members were encouraged to invest $5,000 on the site.  One victim tried to withdraw their funds after trading with the $5,000 investment but was denied.  Another victim invested $22,000 at this stage based on the promise that they would be fully reimbursed if their investment failed.  However, when they tried to withdraw, they were told they could not because one of their trades was “executed late”.  

After a few months of trading on OPACOIN, DAF members were encouraged to invest an additional $50,000.  One victim signed a $50,000 investment contract with DAF Finance Institute, where DAF guaranteed a 300% return on the victim’s investment over just a three-month trading period.  Another victim invested $50,000 into their account, but was told that their investment had completely failed, resulting in a total loss.  This victim was encouraged to keep silent about their losses, and they lost access to the WhatsApp group shortly after.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
Three California consumers report their encounters with a purported cryptocurrency platform and mining operation at using the name Erspce Digital Technology (Erspce) and located online at erspce.org. Erspce claimed to offer daily profits from AI-driven trading. 

The first California consumer joined Erspce after receiving an invitation code from a friend, who would also earn a share of the consumer’s profits. Erspce operated a rewards program where users would supposedly earn more based on the number of referrals and investment amounts, resembling a pyramid scheme. After the consumer joined, Erspce announced a special event tied to its new cryptocurrency, ESP, where users could receive a dollar-for-dollar USDT bonus for deposits made through the TRONSCAN (TRC20) network. The consumer deposited amounts of 122, 13,322, 1,322, and 322 USDT, each time receiving an equal bonus and accumulating 253,666 ESP tokens.

Issues began when the consumer attempted to withdraw 20,000 USDT; Erspce's app experienced downtime, and the site briefly went offline. When services resumed, all pending withdrawal requests were denied due to a supposed system error. Erspce then requested a 30 USDT deposit to facilitate withdrawals, which the consumer declined. Despite initiating a new withdrawal request, it remained unprocessed for over five days, exceeding Erspce’s advertised 72-hour timeline to honor withdrawal requests.

The consumer’s Erspce account interface showed a balance of about 40,000 USDT, but TRONSCAN reflects only $0.01, indicating that the funds were transferred out to an unknown wallet without the consumer’s knowledge. No funds have been recovered.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reports sending funds to the crypto trading platform, E Crypto Trading, at https://e-cryptotrading.com/. The victim believed they were making profits trading on the platform. But when they tried to withdraw funds from the platform, the platform’s customer service demanded the victim pay a “processing fee” charge of roughly $8,000 within 20 days to withdraw their funds. The victim asked if they could pay the fee in installments and was directed to the platform’s “financial department.” After setting up an installment plan to pay the “processing fee,” a customer service representative i for the platform’s said the victim needed to pay another $7,000 “custody fee.” At this point, the victim reported the incident and have not been able to recover any funds from the platform.

Please note that crypto scams involving the use of fraudulent trading platforms may be highly organized and may employ several bad actors posing as members of various departments to appear legitimate. In addition, scammers may use underhanded tactics such as imposing arbitrary deadlines to create a false sense of urgency.

(Entity Impersonating Currency Exchange International)
complaint_narrative:
Four Californians reported their experiences interacting with a crypto asset trading platform that appears to be impersonating the foreign exchange service Currency Exchange International (CXI).

The first victim was invited via WhatsApp to join a trading group, led by a person named professor, that taught crypto asset trading and recommended the platform CXIPro.com. The Professor’s assistant, Riley, persuaded the victim to open an account with $1,000 and begin trading. Within 3 months, and after making several more deposits, of the victim’s account showed profits of $1,324,663. But when the victim attempted to withdraw funds, the platform demanded that the victim pay a tax of 10% of their account value. The platform continued to send emails threatening that unless the taxes were paid, the account would be disabled or even permanently closed. When the victim didn’t pay, Riley reached out to the victim and told them that CXIPro.com was switching to a new website www.cxisux.com and provided another invite code. However, to transfer the funds, the victim would have to pay the taxes. The victim has been unable to withdraw any funds from their account. 

The second victim was also invited to join a group of investors via WhatsApp. The victim deposited funds to CXI Pro and was able to withdraw $1,000. Feeling confident, the victim deposited more funds. But when they tried to make another withdrawal, the platform informed the victim that they would not be able to withdraw funds, since their trading volume was too low and they had exceeded the withdraw limit.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

Pig Butchering Scam

Investment Group Scam

primary_subject:

cxipro.com
cxisux.com
(Entity Impersonating Currency Exchange International)
(cont.)
complaint_narrative:
The third victim joined a WhatsApp investment group where a person named Brendan claimed to have a ton of knowledge and offered trading signals to help members make profits trading crypto assets. After watching the group’s activity for a while, the victim transferred money to CXIPro to make trades. After investing $11,000, the platform showed that the victim had doubled their money. But the victim has been unable to withdraw any funds from the platform.

The fourth victim invested money with CXIPro and at some point, was contacted via email and told that they failed to make payment in accordance with regulations of the Financial Crimes Law Enforcement Agency. The email went on to say that unless they made a deposit, their account would be frozen. The victim believes their account balance is more than $167,319 but has been unable to withdraw any funds. 

This is not to be confused with the foreign exchange service, Currency Exchange International (CXI) at https://www.ceifx.com/.

The sites associated with CXI Pro linked above are no longer operational.

But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform said that their funds were being held by the Federal Reserve bank. complaint_narrative:
A California resident reports being approached by “Ethan” on the dating app Bumble. After some conversation, Ethan suggested they move their conversations over to WhatsApp. Ethan said he worked for a reputable fashion company and managed multiple stores in the west coast. Ethan regularly sent photos of himself and said he wanted to meet in person on several occasions. Over time, Ethan began to encourage the victim to invest in crypto. Ethan guided the victim through the process of opening an account at a crypto exchange and then suggested that the victim invest in crypto options through the trading platform www.crypto-btctep.com and www.crypto-btcdeal.com. The victim made an initial investment of $1,000 on the platform and was able to withdraw $140 back into their checking account. Convinced the platform was legitimate, the victim continued to trade on the platform and deposited more money into their account. But when the victim attempted to withdraw $100,000 from the platform, Ethan informed them they would need to pay 25% of the profits earned for “tax related reasons” before their funds could be released. All told the victim transferred more than $200,000 to the platform and has been unable to withdraw any funds. 

The sites are no longer operational.

primary_subject:
Yun Shang Hui Xin Limited
yunshfex.com
complaint_narrative:
A Californian reports they got a text message from “Shirley” who asked to continue their conversations through WhatsApp. During their conversations, Shirley sent multiple photos and videos of herself, but wouldn’t agree to talk through video calls. At some point, Shirley brought up investing in crypto and directed the victim to her trading broker, Yun Shang Hui Xin Limited, and helped them opened an account at http://www.yunshfex.com. Under Shirley’s instruction, the victim wired at least $25,000 to the fraudulent platform and has not been able to recover their funds. The victim reported sending funds to the Ethereum wallet address: 0xb8E2C1BA095bb446C676F9Ce2A903a4A33367F58. 

The site is no longer operational.

The DFPI cautions that, traditionally, when interacting with someone you do not know through a social media or messaging platform, one potential indicator that the other party may be scammer could be an aversion on their part to engage in live interactions (e.g. meeting in person, having video calls). However, that alone does not confirm fraudulent activity, as scammers may use various tactics to manipulate their appearance, such as using actors/actresses to engage in live interactions on their behalf. In addition, please note that with ongoing advancements in AI, scammers may become increasingly adept at leveraging generative AI and deepfake technologies to manipulate their appearance and deceive potential victims.
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reported that “Alex” contacted them through WeChat. After some conversation, Alex convinced the resident to move their conversation over to WhatsApp, and they developed a relationship. At some point, Alex encouraged the resident to invest in crypto assets and provided step-by-step instructions through screenshots how to open an account on a crypto exchange.  Alex also introduced the resident to a friend named “Summer” who said she could teach the resident how to invest in crypto assets for short-term gain.  Under both Alex and Summer’s guidance, the resident transferred crypto assets to the exchange at www.celestia.bet.  But when the resident tried to withdraw funds from the platform, Celestia customer service asked for proper identification before any crypto would be released.   The resident submitted their driver’s license and videos of them holding their driver’s license.  When this didn’t work, the resident reached out to Alex for help.  Alex told the resident that Summer's friend had similar withdrawal issues, but they fixed it by depositing more crypto assets onto the exchange.  Alex encouraged the resident do the same.  

Alex also suggested they try a new crypto exchange called Bitix at www.bitix.net and encouraged the resident to transfer more crypto assets to that exchange.

All told, the victim transferred $127,629 to these exchanges and has been unable to recover any of it.  None of the websites involved are currently operational. 

This is not to be confused with the Celestia crypto network at https://celestia.org/ or the bitcoin futures fund, ProFunds BITIX.

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reported a crypto site that claimed to earn daily returns for users using “AI crypto arbitrage trading”. The site promised a 1% daily return on deposited funds. Although the site’s domain was cbdexapi.pro, the site used the branding of a highly popular crypto exchange to mislead users.

The victim deposited funds with cbdexapi.pro which showed they would indeed earn a 1% daily return. The victim was able to withdraw money for a few days. However, when they attempted to make another withdrawal, the site claimed that because their account balance had fallen below the site’s liquidity requirement, they would need to deposit more money. The victim did so, and tried to withdraw, but were told that their withdrawal would take 50 days to process because of “blockchain congestion”. After 50 days, the victim contacted the site again. This time, the victim was told they needed to pay 15% of their account balance for “technical support” from the “Federal Reserve’s blockchain regulator”. The victim has been unable to withdraw their money and the site is no longer active.

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reported that they were introduced to a crypto trading site called zhibitexap.com by someone they met on LinkedIn named Wang. Wang told the victim they could teach them how to make large profits from crypto trading on zhibitexap.com. Wang guided the victim through setting up their account on Zhibite, and overseeing all trades and transactions.

The victim began trading by depositing $1,000 in their Zhibite account, which yielded a $200 profit that they were able to successfully withdraw. Based on this transaction, the victim moved $10,000 more into their Zhibite account, which appeared to generate a profit of about $10,000. Wang convinced the victim that the optimal trading amount on Zhibite is $50,000, so the victim took out a loan of $20,000 and transferred it to Zhibite. Wang then told the victim if they transferred $10,000 more, he would match it.

Through a series of trades, the victim believed they had earned a profit of about $85,000. However, when the victim tried to withdraw, they were told they needed to first pay a 20% service fee within three days, or a 1% late penalty would begin to accrue. The victim asked if they could pay the fee using their trading gains, but the site said the fee must be paid with separate funds. The victim paid the “service fee” but was told they needed to make additional trades to withdraw their balance. The victim made another trade that appeared to yield over $110,000 of profit. However, the site told the victim they now needed to pay a $22,000 “service fee” within two days to avoid affecting the victim’s credit score. The victim has been unable to withdraw their money and lost over $50,000 in total. The site is now down.

Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
Three Californians reported the DeFi platform LONTL.

The first victim reported being pinged on their phone by “XiaoXiao”, who claimed to be a Singapore native that moved to California to work as a fashion designer. They continued to communicate and developed a relationship.  One day, XiaoXiao shared an investment opportunity involving their “aunt” who worked in Wall Street and managed a team of analysts that traded crypto options. Xiao Xiao said if the victim put money into a digital wallet and invested in the decentralized application (dApp), LONTL, the “aunt” could give them trading signals. To further entice the victim, XiaoXiao offered to subsidize the victim’s account on the platform. The victim transferred money and began to trade with Xiao Xiao. After several trading sessions, the victim believed their account had grown to more than $1.4 million. But, when the victim attempted to withdraw funds, the platform said that their account had been frozen and they needed to pay $73,000 to unlock it., When they expressed concern, a representative of the platform said that they would cover $30,000 if the victim put in the rest. The victim has not been able to recover their funds. 

The second victim was approached by “Rina” online who at some point talked about options trading on the LONTL platform at https://www.lontl-fx.com/#/. The victim invested $2,000 in ETH and was able to withdraw $200 from the platform. Convinced that the platform was legitimate, the victim transferred more money to platform, and after a few weeks of trading, believed their account had grown to $1.2 million. But when the victim tried to make a withdrawal, the platform said they needed to pay 10% of their account balance, or $120,000, for “comprehensive management fees”. The victim paid this in installments, but the platform only asked for more arbitrary fees. The victim has not been able to recover any funds from the platform. All told, they lost more $199,000.

primary_subject:

complaint_narrative:
A Californian reported that a friend of a friend named “Sasha” reached out on Instagram and claimed to be a crypto trader.  Sasha informed the Californian that she helps people make money by trading crypto on their behalf, even guaranteeing profits within 3 hours. Under Sasha’s instructions, the victim opened a digital wallet and initially transferred $1,000 from their checking account to purchase, which they then sent to the wallet address per Sasha's direction at to 0x83cA775F45Ca6E979414e71B10F49ac7685aFEde. The victim then received a link to the website, Spikefxfasttrade.com, to register for an account. After trading on the platform for a few hours, the victim was led to believe their account grew to $15,000. But when they attempted to withdraw funds, they were not able to do so because of technical issues with the website. The victim reached out to Sasha, and she informed the victim that they needed to pay $3,500 in “mining fees” before they could make a withdrawal. Sasha assured the victim that the fee would add back into their profits and allow them to be able to withdraw all their profits. So, the victim paid the $3,500, and watched the balance of the account on the platform climb to $20,000.  But they were still not able to withdraw the funds. Then another company called Upward Fox  sent the victim an email demanded $7,000 for a “withdrawal fee”. Sasha confirmed that the $7,000 withdrawal fee was needed to release their profits, but again assured that the withdrawal fee would be added back to their account. When the victim said they couldn’t pay, they were offered a reduced withdrawal fee if they paid through PayPal or CashApp. The victim has not been able to recover any of their funds. Later, they found out the friend who Sasha claimed to know had had their Instagram account hacked. The platform is no longer operational.

Victims reported sending funds to the following address:   0x83cA775F45Ca6E979414e71B10F49ac7685aFEde
scam_type:
Fraudulent Trading Platform

complaint_narrative:
Two California residents reported on their experiences investing in the crypto asset trading platform, “Tether Pool.”

The first victim accessed the Tether Pool platform via the website tetherpool.art.  The victim reported depositing over $9,500 into the platform, but the website denied the victim's withdrawal request. 

The second victim reported meeting an individual online who advised them to purchase the cryptocurrency Ethereum and send it to the Tether Pool platform at thetherpool.top via the wallet address 0xd68f7E162BA2697684e544A424A0ca6886D82345. Their initial investment seemed to grow in value.

But when the victim attempted to withdraw their funds, Tether Pool’s customer service demanded they pay a tax before withdrawals could be made.  Despite paying the tax, Tether Pool’s customer service repeatedly told the victim that their withdrawal was delayed due to too many other customers’ withdrawals being processed. After several months of waiting, customer service advised the victim that their withdrawal was rejected and that they needed to pay a $30,000 “special handling fee” to expedite the withdrawal. However, two weeks later, the victim was unable to contact customer service or the individual that told them about Tether Pool to begin with. 

This victim has not recovered any of the funds they deposited on the site. These websites are no longer operational.

But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, they were told their "credit score" had dropped by one point and they needed to pay a $10,000 "recharge" fee to restore it to 100 points. After complying, they were informed that the delay had caused their score to drop further, and now an additional $50,000 was required to bring the score back to 100.

complaint_narrative:
A California resident reported they were contacted on Twitter by someone claiming to be a popular YouTube crypto asset influencer and convinced the resident to move their conversations over to WhatsApp.  At some point, the imposter told the resident about the Flare token airdrop and convinced the resident they could claim some of these Flare tokens.  The imposter then provided the resident a link through WhatsApp at https://flrmeshworknet.us.  However, the resident received an error message after clicking the link to enter their wallet keys, and was then unable  to recover any of their money. All told, the resident reported losing $63,543.92 on this website, which is no longer operational.

Please note that airdrops are a marketing strategy that involves sending coins or tokens to wallet addresses to promote a new cryptocurrency or new token. Airdrops are often associated with the launch of a new cryptocurrency or DeFi protocol. While airdrops can be used to promote legitimate projects, DFPI urges consumers to be cautious, as there are also scams that involve the promotion of airdrops.

Victims reported sending funds to the following address:  rLEFT4k54Pd1k73iqAsA24S8rqKYv5wWrG.

primary_subject:
h5.coinmatevip.com
(Entity Impersonating the intergovernmental organization Financial Action Task Force, FATF)
complaint_narrative:
Three Californians reported about the crypto asset trading platform coinmatevip.com.

The first victim met “LinXinXin” and “Scarlett” online, who claimed to be “consortium administrators” for the crypto trading platform, h5.coinmate.vip.com and encouraged the victim to open an account. Over a period of months and under the instructions of LinXinXin and Scarlett, the victim deposited funds to the platform.  All told, they transferred $650,000 to the platform and has not been able to recover any of that.

The second victim met “Leena” via text message. Leena claimed to be a Hong Kong native that moved to Boston to work for a prominent consulting firm. After a few conversations, Leena invited the victim to join an investing group on Telegram and open a trading account at h5.coinmatevip.com. The victim then transferred crypto assets to the platform. Over the course of three months, the victim participated with members of the group chat in various option trades on the platform. At one point, the victim believed their account balance had increased to $1.1 million. But when the victim tried to withdraw their money, the platform demanded an upfront fee of $133,000.  All told, the victim transferred $330,00 to the platform and has not been able to recover any of it.

The third victim also reported being invited to join an “investment consortium” on Telegram. At the direction of the group chat, they opened an account and transferred funds to a UK-based trading platform called coinmatevp.com. After a few months, the investment group on Telegram disbanded, but the victim was still able to trade and their account experienced significant growth on the platform. But when the victim tried to withdraw funds, the platform demanded they pay “tax and consortium fee payments”. The victim paid, but coinmatevp.com informed them that their funds were frozen by the “World Anti-Money Laundering Task Force (FATF)” due to unusual trading activities and they would need to pay an additional $50,000  to confirm they were not involved in money laundering activities. At this point the victim realized that the platform is a scam and reported the incident. It is noted that the victim received the money laundering notification from coinmatevip, not the intergovernmental organization Financial Action Task Force (FATF). The victim has not been able to recover any of their money.

Victims reported sending funds to the following address:  0xba909bd6cd78bd9ba9c491d400821ff2bedd003b

The websites associated with this platform are no longer operational.

Fraudulent Trading Platform
